awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Well-Defined Hybrid Materials as a Versatile Tool to Study Energy Transfer Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
One of the main challenges facing humanity in the 21st century is the supply of secure and sustainable energy, of which consumption will only continue to grow as the human population increases. This project tackles the engineering and design of well-defined hybrid materials, which could be applied towards effective solar energy utilization. Metal-organic crystalline materials produced by self-assembly could enable us to reach these goals and, thereby, affect the state of future energy generation and storage. This project also integrates the development of the Carolinian Women in Science (Wi-Sci) Supportive Network, which addresses the workforce demand in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The proposed Wi-Sci initiative integrates educational and research opportunities for female students in STEM disciplines by establishing intercollegiate scientific exchanges and collaborations, providing and promoting multidisciplinary research opportunities for female scientists in different research groups, and organizing educational workshops focused on attraction and retention of women in the STEM disciplines. The major goal of the Wi-Sci initiative is to create and grow a network of support at more than 60 Carolinian institutions of higher education, including 20 historically black colleges and universities, and, therefore, increase opportunities for women to occupy at least 50% of the new positions projected for STEM disciplines in the Carolinas.

Technical Abstract
Energy transfer in a predesigned pathway is an emerging field of interest for a broad scientific community and required for the development of the next generation of solar cells, photocatalysts, sensors, light-emitting diodes, and switches. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research and the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B program in the Division of Chemistry, the major goal of this project is the preparation of crystalline hybrid materials with a predesigned pathway for energy transfer that significantly enhance energy utilization efficiency and, thereby, drastically modify the existing energy and material landscape. The advantages of utilizing the proposed materials for energy transfer studies are as follows: (i) scaffold modularity, which allows tuning of photophysical properties of the material; (ii) crystallinity, which provides a platform for systematic studies of energy transfer mechanisms compared to amorphous polymers; and (iii) porosity, in combination with structural modularity, which allows studying of different energy transfer pathways involving organic linkers, metal nodes, and guest molecules. Moreover, the self-assembly approach proposed for material synthesis allows replication of the hierarchical organization of hundreds of chromophores observed in the natural photosystem. Integration of educational and research opportunities for high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students, with a special emphasis on women in STEM disciplines, is also a top priority of this project.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this award shed light on structural principles governing energy transfer, and therefore, contributed to the basic science of fullerene/corannulene chemistry as well as the photoinduced energy transfer mechanisms necessary for organic photovoltaics (OPVs) and molecular electronics development, especially taking into account a great interest in crystalline fullerene-based materials required for engineering of an OPV active layer. Furthermore, we designed the first field-effect transistor based on photochromic metal-organic frameworks, which utilizes the benefits of combining photochromic derivatives with metal-organic frameworks. Furthermore, we showed that our photochromic materials can be utilized for dynamic control of electronic profiles of semiconductors, which is a completely new avenue in porous semiconducting materials. Moreover, we have demonstrated a way to mimic protein β-barrel-chromophore interactions by immobilization of the corresponding chromophore inside a crystalline porous scaffold, which dictates the chromophore molecular conformation and, therefore, affects its photophysics. The results of this work funded by this project has been featured on the covers of Journal of American Chemical Society (JASC), Angewandte Chemie International Edition, MRS, and Chemical Society Review as well as in Emerging Investigator Issue, Noteworthy Chemistry, New Talents: Americas, JACS Young Investigator Issue, Special Issue: Laying Groundwork for the Future, and Future Directions of Reticular Chemistry.

This NSF grant also enables the development of young scientists including training for 13 graduate and 38 undergraduate students whose work resulted in more than 27 scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals. The students who worked on this project have acquired extensive training in synthetic organic, organometallic, and inorganic chemistry as well as photophysical measurements. All graduate students engaged in the project have found jobs prior to graduation and continue their careers at Intel, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Savannah River National Laboratory, Nephron Pharmaceutical, Claflin University, and Wake Forest University. The graduate students have been selected as recipients of a number of awards among which Breakthrough Graduate Scholars award, a Dera D. Parkinson Trustee Fellowship, Winifred Burks-Houck Graduate Student Leadership Award, Oakwood Chemical Company Senior Graduate Award, ACS Travel Award, Photochem Symposium best poster award, and SPARC Research Fellowships. Among undergraduate researchers, ten of them have received the competitive Magellan Research Scholarships. For the work in the PI’s group, the undergraduate researchers have received ACS Division of Inorganic Chemistry Undergraduate Award, Scholarships for Excellence in Chemistry, Royal Society of Chemistry Certificate of Excellence, SC-AMP Summer Fellowship, Undergraduate Research Conference Poster Award, and many others.

This award has also supported the Women-in-Science (Wi-Sci) Supportive Network with the main focus on retention of female scientists in STEM disciplines, initiated by the PI and continued with the help of the PI’s group members. The PI and her group have solely organized research and educational events as a part of the Wi-Sci program for more than 120 students at the historically black Claflin and Allen Universities (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wEcE2H4WPMk, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJ8cV3cpUj4). The Wi-Sci program also included the workshop for more than 50 female students from STEM departments at the USC campus (https://www.shustovalab.org/wi-sci) and the discussion panel relative to efficient time management for 30 female faculty, staff, and postdoctoral associates during the Women Leadership Institute Event. Moreover, this grant has provided the support for the event organized by the PI for female high school students from the greater Columbia area who visited USC for the “Life in Color” Materials Program Event (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kXMrXf8Jgq4&t=1s).


Last Modified: 05/27/2022
Modified by: Natalia Shustova
